Headline: M&A | PE | Quant | Passed CFA Level 3
Comment: I did that ‚Äòthrow everything at building an MVP and the VC money will come‚Äô  guess what it didn‚Äôt come, I lost money (dad‚Äôs money) lost time, lost mental health ( I was barely 23) Took my L and followed the work path. Passed CFA exams, moved to London got a job, made a semi decent life. It‚Äôs difficult to bounce back but one can do it. I still want to start a business but now I‚Äôm older, wiser and most importantly I will never throw everything at it with the hopes that the VC money will come, in fact this time around I don‚Äôt want VC money, I don‚Äôt want a hyper growth business, I want to build something that is profitable, that I like doing and is meaningful.

Headline: Helping early-stage founders feel heard | VC Analyst @ Equanimity Investments | CFA Charterholder
Comment:
Our willingness to take on debt is slowly turning into a problem, not just from a VC/Startups lens, but as a country in general. 

EMIs have jumped from 46% of household income in 2020 to 61% in 2024 - lead by easier availability of credit and FOMO of 'Oh, they're doing it, so I can too'.

Headline: Open to work.
Comment:
Idk, but something is off about your approach to finding. Unless we are talking about just access to capital. 

your play book doesn‚Äôt sound like it‚Äôs best fit for VC, rather for PE. Of course you have every right to expect great returns. But simply expecting that doesn‚Äôt make one a VC, unless the very definition of it has changed. 

what you are talking about is minimising there risk of investment and maximising returns. What VCs, the great ones, are known for is to spot great potential and consequently great returns. No one ever invests clearly knowing something is wrong or could be wrong. 

for all the attributes you have rejected funding and aren‚Äôt keen, others have invested. 

You are free, absolutely to invest in anywhere you wish to, and trust me no one owes you anything for your efforts. That‚Äôs on you. But when people read and internalise these opinions, it creates a culture that has been the central motif (not necessarily healthy), of Indian VC. 

all I would do is wait for a decade, if I am alive and see how your portfolio has done
